commentBody: Love a fun theme on a Tuesday!! Entering "Loo" for "Lav" added a good minute to my time today, haha.
I hate it when loo is lav! Took me awhile to figure it out. A great debut, Jonathan! Thanks. Hope y‚Äôall have a terrific Tuesday!
Masts on a battleship is certainly stretching the definitions of both unless referring to a rarely-attested archaic shortening.

Congrats on your debut, Jonathon! That‚Äôs persistence! Folks, this is a quality debut and well earned. It is no joke to find good backward themers for any theme, much less fit four decent ones and a long revealer in a grid with smooth enough fill for a Tuesday (and this was very smooth fill with a few additional interesting entries like DETOXTEA and LIPSYNC.) Great job!
Finally I hate to keep harping on ‚ÄúThings I learned from Survivor‚Äù but literally, as I was doing this puzzle, I had Survivor 24 on and a character was saying ‚ÄúI was trying to be less threatening, so I acted more like a BETA male than an Alpha‚Äù. Not that I haven‚Äôt heard that term used that way IRL, or clued that way in a puzzle (usually it‚Äôs BETA testing or the Greek letter)‚Äîbut neither often. Cue the Twilight Zone music‚Ä¶
i'd love to be able to create a puzzle like this one.  it was fun throughout.
CAPITAL Tuesday puzzle!

I had a hoot doing this puzzle.

It provided exactly the level of mental engagement I needed.

So, if any of you didn't like it...well...what can I say?

You're wrong.

(I must be in the "embarrassingly pugnacious" part of my cycle.)

Great debut, Mr. Baude!

I, too, hope it's not another twenty years.  I doubt that I'll be solving many puzzles 20 years from now.

So get to work!
Well done. I just wish the circles could be easier to see.

Fun puzzle overall, but I did find it jarring to see "lamer" in this context.

I know people argue about whether this is a genuinely offensive term, but especially in an official NYT crossword (and a crossword that has ASL as one of the other hints!) it strikes me as something that should have ideally been caught and removed in editing.  Why use language around disability in that way?  We have so many other options.

Wait a minute here.  You've got to be kidding me.

Surely you know that Natick is the capital of Massachusetts. No, not out there in the Sunken Place. Here, in Crosslandia. 

In Natick, when two residents cross paths unexpectedly, they both pretend they've forgotten each other's names and start guessing out loud, getting angrier and angrier with each other until they stalk off in separate directions. In the beautiful State House, where Massachusetts legislation takes place, bills rarely pass because the members of the house accuse each other of unfairly putting words and language in the text they can't understand or even pronounce. It gets pretty ugly in Natick, let me tell you! And six-term Governor Rex Parker refuses to do anything about it!

Back to the puzzle. Funny solid Tuesday, took me a little longer than usual and I appreciated that, meant Mr. Baude was doing well.  Also liked that AMOR is also a raised capital: ROMA is the capitale d'Italia. With Oslo thrown in for good measure (there must be more to Oslo than Munch, or is that a Scream you've heard before?) Also liked the 2 billion duo, especially since the answers are nearly anagrams -- Islam / gmail. And I know it was meant well, but I believe certain enthusiasts here might take exception to hairball hackers.  I fear, Mr. Baude, that this may come back to haunt you.

LOO/LAV the Kea-Loa of UK restrooms?

Good to think back on Joe Pesci in Goodfellows. That's such a grand movie.
I really admire your tenaciousness, Jonathan, and you‚Äôve created a terrific Tuesday puzzle.

And there it was. You fill in the grid at such a fast pace, quick leap accross, down, hit your stride, last word, and . . .


I'm gonna sit right down
And find myself a letter
And wonder if you missed it too

I'm gonna fight to keep my streak
There ain't a word that got us beat
A lot of cussing while we fought 'em
We'll be glad we got 'em

I'm gonna smile and say
"Well don't just moan you fretter!"
Flyspecking is
The thing to do

I'm gonna sit right down
And find myself a letter
It may be that EMAIL won't do

I'm gonna sit right down
And snailmail ain't no better 
It's gotta be GMAIL for you

Cool math things I learned today:

ONE state name has a single syllable
Almost TWO BILLION people subscribe to Islam
Almost TWO BILLION people use GMail
I figured out the theme pretty quickly, but had to search up the remaining state capitals I hadn't found yet :P

Top of the hour on radio where the term originated I understand - is when the hour turns ie 6pm into 7pm, 7am into 8am etc, when you expect the news and weather to be aired. Not just midnight and noon as per the read about column. So 12 isn‚Äôt really the answer.
Congratulations on your debut.

Congratulations, Mr. Baude, on a fabulous debut! I was very moved by the backstory and how you never gave up. It makes it pretty perfect that you included Mary Tyler Moore in the entries. Remember that intro to The MTM Show? "...you're gonna make it after all..." https://youtu.be/ZNKOt2k7Pm4?si=dC3725qJSu0MtRAG Maybe you have a fedora lying around or even a beanie will do...now twirl and throw it in the air because you deserve the happiness and celebration. Thank you for a superb puzzle and all my respect, sir!
love me a surprise amuse-bouche thursday on a tuesday.
ASL is a language, not a communication system. It's not only inaccurate to call it a communication system, but it's deeply offensive to the Deaf community to deny its status as a language.
Cool trick the paired clues for GMAIL and ISLAM.

As usual, I completely missed the themed entries. Very clever indeed!
This was a fun and challenging solve. Seemed a bit tougher than usual for a Tuesday.
Very American, I was 10 minutes slower than usual :(

Congratulations, Jonathan Baude.Your puzzle was a pleasure to work, and just right for a Tuesday.   Your family must be thrilled to see you here. 

Thank you, and I'm sure we'll see you again.

Meh. The theme was quite interesting and well implemented, but I didn't enjoy the trivia-heavy fill. I didn't need lookups, but I was tempted to take same throughout my solve. Belvedere vodka was originally a Polish brand, and it's still distilled exclusively in Poland. It was one of our first premium vodka brands. The name comes from the neoclassical Belweder palace, for decades the residence of Polish heads of state: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belweder Poland and Polish things don't often feature in these puzzles. I found it a bit sad that when it made an appearance today, it was via vodka, the world's least interesting type of alcohol, and a symbol of Polish uncultured, heavy drinking.

Noticed TOPEKA immediately, as I used to visit there occasionally, and it's where I took my licensing exam to become an RN in 1975. Five multi-hour tests over two days, which they now do on computer in one session in much less time.

Jonathan, I'm glad you persevered and got to provide us with this excellent puzzle. I found it slightly harder than a usual Tuesday, but my big delay was finding a typo where I probably used the right finger but on the wrong hand (V vs M).

I thought the old gray lady was finally about to TAKEPOT only to be geographically challenged. 

Nice puzzle. 

A bit Wednesdayish.

I'm trying to think of a pun about state capitals. I'll have Topeka good one.

(But it's Raleigh hard to do!)
absolutely pierre-less puzzle today...
Oof‚Ä¶ very well constructed, kudos to Jonathan! But seemed tougher than a usual Tuesday and generally frustrating for people outside the US. Either way congrats on the debut!!!

Hand up for entering Loo for LAV. As @john ezra pointed out, it appears to be the KEA/LOA of UK bathrooms ü§£ If you‚Äôve never seen LIP SYNC Battle, you‚Äôve been missing out. This was the first episode that launched the series and hooked me. I couldn‚Äôt stop laughing ü§£ Dwayne Johnson was brilliant and Jimmy Fallon never disappoints. https://youtu.be/Xn3tUOJ9yv4?si=VC5UIxk-re9LJBSO Excellent debut, Jonathan! I‚Äôm glad that you kept at it for so long and hope to see your next one soon.

Only one capital doesn‚Äôt share any letters with its state.  

One of my favorite trivia questions.

Congratulations on a terrific debut, Jonathan.  Now that you've concord this goal, I hope to see more from you.



You have to say it like they say it in NH.
I puzzled over OTOH. But I sure remember the days of ONCD! üìö ü¶ñ

As a pastry chef (even if my job description has changed a bit in the last year), I'm irritated just a tad by the description of S'MORE as a "dessert item," but √âCLAIR as "decadent." Why "decadent"? Because it's French, and has a diacritic in it's name? But then, "s'more" has an unnecessary punctuation mark; and if we're talking empty calories, I'd say s'mores have √©clairs beat hands down. In fact, s'mores and √©clairs bear certain morphological similarities: a rather bland flour-based shell enclosing an overly-sweet, gooey filling, with chocolate added, inside or on top. √âclairs are made with cream puff pastry*, which is one of the quickest and easiest doughs to prepare, if somewhat messy to clean up. True, for √©lcairs you need to make a custard (cr√®me p√¢tissi√®re) and chocolate glaze, but, hey, even instant pudding will do in a pinch. Even the great poet Maya Angelou knew that: https://www.npr.org/2014/06/01/317843650/maya-angelou-foodie (When I heard that segment air, I said "Yes! Someone who finally gets it!") *not to be confused with "puff pastry," which is one of the most difficult and labor-intensive. In French, they are called "p√¢te √† choux" and "p√¢te feuillet√©e," respectively, so you'd never get the two mixed up, even though they both have *two* diacritics in their names.

Huh! Finally looked it up, and found out that ACAI is pronounced aa-saa-ee, with the accent on the last syllable.





Et tu, emu.
Emus are hungry today!
Excellent puzzle Jonathan ‚Äì here's hoping your next one is just around the corner!

Why, just the other day, my Partner and I were reminiscing how quaint those villages were AT NALTAr Bala and AT NALTAr Paain, in Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan. The region is quite picturesque, and quite the ski mecca, birthplace of alpine skier Muhammad Abbas, first Pakistani to compete in the Winter Olympics (2010).

I love it when a constructor comes up with a theme idea that you‚Äôd think would have been done before.  You‚Äôd think that among the mass of constructors over the many years, someone would have come across the phrase RAISING CAPITAL and thought to do what Jonathan did.  There it was, low hanging fruit, and nobody saw it ‚Äì until:

Jonathan, who had been submitting puzzles for TWENTY YEARS with no success ‚Äì who followed every rejection with another submission! ‚Äì saw it.  Who better deserves this lovely theme than one with such persistence.

I am so inspired by grit like that.  

Oh, lovely puzzle with its tight tight theme, and little extras like AMP crossing IMP, like a backward ROMA to cast a faint echo to the theme (Hi, @John Ezra!), like a backward TOPS to go with ELITE, and like the sweet Puzzpair¬© of CAPITAL/ONE.

So, thank you for the fun, Jonathan, but mostly, thank you for a backstory that will stick with me for AGES.  Bravo!
I love today's column pic! That was one of the strangest productions of "Oedipus Rex" I've ever seen.
Sort of a chewy little tuesday innit!!! Excellent debut Jonathan!

Nice to see a shout-out for the Regina Carhops, whose brief but notorious stint in the NHL has made them verboten content in Canadian crossword puzzles. Also, don‚Äôt look for official records online, definitely NSFW.*

And personally, I‚Äôm not learning much from crosswords. Haven‚Äôt retained a single surface area measurement of a NY state parcel of land, nor the secondary intercardinal directions between any major US population centres. But I‚Äôm having fun, Mom!


*Not Something Fact-worthy.
Fun crossword - kept me on my toes!
Is 'acai' the new 'oreo'? Healthier, but not as tasty.

In retrospect, BOTOXTEA might not be a good choice for a cleanse. But with SLOB rather than CLOD at first, in it went.

Got the revealer and the themers almost instantly, but still needed more than ten minutes to get this one done.

Wouldn't call this puzzle a HOOT, but have certainly seen LAMER. Congrats on the debut.

Fave entries: ONCD audiobooks and the very genius XII for ‚ÄúTop of the hour?‚Äù 

But better than any individual entry or the delightful theme is the backstory of the constructor‚Äôs 20-year quest to get a puzzle before us. Big congratulations, Jonathan! You‚Äôre inspiring.

Solved my 2,000th NYT crossword today!

Weeeee!

Kind of a tough Tuesday for me, but ended up being an enjoyable workout; and tumbling to the theme was a big help also. That's always a nice touch. A couple of puzzle finds today - the first one fairly appropriate. A Sunday from August 10, 1969 by Kirk Dodd with the title: "Capital ideas." Some theme answers in that one (straightforwardly clued): TRENTONPERIOD STEPHENAUSTIN CONCORDGRAPES LITTLEROCKS WALTERRALEIGH ROBERTLANSING BOSTONTERRIER And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=8/10/1969&g=58&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ....

Fun puzzle, and an excellent debut! I have a huge amount of respect for the constructor to have kept at this one thing for so long, even in the face of rejection. I'm the kind of person who picks up a hobby and then drops it three months later.

Fun, clever puzzle!

Not fond at all of the BETA clue.  There are thousands of other ways to clue it that don't call attention to fearful manosphere BS.

Absolutely loved this one. I found the sticking points largely workable through the crosses and some context clues. Mostly clever cluing (especially loved Top of the Hour?). The West-most square having BITE, SPOT and DETOXTEA showed the constructor‚Äôs weakness, however, as too many generalized answers for those clues created a bit of a natick (not sure what a conglomerate of generic terms in a crossword would be, so forgive the possible misuse of that word) and made that square largely impenetrable for me. Again, I‚Äôm calling for the Wordplay column writers to include some of the actually tricky clues in their Tricky Clues section. Looking forward for more from this constructor soon! Stay warm!

I thought 38D should have been DAMNING WITH FAINT PRAISE--either the clue OR the entry, really.  
"I'll take 'Obscure Liquor Brands' for a thousand, Ken,"  might work for 15D.
Um, PG MOVIES are "family-friendly"??  Not necessarily so--or you wouldn't need GUIDANCE.  That's not to say it can't be a way to introduce and discuss touchy topics, but I'd rethink that clue.

I am a bit distressed by the narwhal/penguin morphs/cryptids in the photo.  

Plus, all you folks in DOVER and BOSTON, please keep your weather to yourselves.  Our sasanquas have just this year recovered from the three-day deep-freeze two years ago that dang-near killed every single shrub.  I went out walking at 6:30 this morning, and believe me, I had the place to myself (wind-chill 27 degrees F.)

Well, the impressive construction and the very apt revealer were completely wasted on me since I didn't need them to solve.¬† Which always seems to me like such a waste of constructing chops.¬† But I enjoyed the puzzle in all the other ways.¬† The cluing is better than Tuesday level:¬† ONE; XII, DRAG, SKATE, TIS.¬† And especially S'MORE.¬† Also, TAKE POTSHOTS AT is a really colorful and original long Down.¬† To have it contain a theme answer -- even though I didn't notice that while solving -- is quite impressive.

Some thoughts:As you all know, I don't drive.¬† So I was quite amazed to learn that carhops SKATE to you.¬† They do???¬† Wow!!!¬† How thrilling!!!

Note to Tik Tokers¬† who LIP SYNC.¬† Why would anyone watch you when there are real singers out there?¬† Just asking for a friend.

As you already know, coping with the icons¬†and the symbols and the trying to guess WHERE on the page all the various "instructions" reside in GMAIL is way above my pay grade.¬† Why this infuriatingly confusing and user-unfriendly platform is the choice of two billion people is beyond me.
¬†¬†
Quite enjoyable Tuesday, I thought.
--
M-E-L-A-S is Salem backwards, the capital of the state of Oregon. Personally, I find the circles distracting and the grid difficult to see.
Mr. Baude is a Northern Michigan man, according to our local paper. Congratulations on persevering and achieving this goal. The puzzle was spot on for a Tuesday‚Äîand I don‚Äôt mean ACNE.

I bet there‚Äôs some muddle-headed,
half-awake solver somewhere
who plopped in eMAIL
and then got the
‚Äú‚Ä¶at least one square‚Ä¶‚Äù
and stared at 
pEMOVIES for an embarrassingly long time,
before getting the G.

Silly, silly solver‚Ä¶
MMA is gross.  It doesn‚Äôt deserve to be in anyone‚Äôs NYT puzzle.

Congratulations to the newly published setter. What a feat.

For me, this time, a few I didn't know. I thought the Grey Goose competition must be some sort of race in Alaska. Didn't get VODKA until the end. Also, Stephen Colbert and his 'home', OCASIO. 44A "We have the meats"? ARBYS - is that a famous butcher? MARY? LYPSYNC. Obvious to most of you, I expect! 

I didn't solve the theme, spent too much time pondering the crossers and trying to solve the clues. I don't think I'd ever thought of states having capitals. (And Dover is on the Kent coast!)

The 'trivia' debate no doubt will rumble on. The one clue I think would count as trivia is the brand name of the breakfast brand, one that's not used any more. To me, all parts of that are trivia!

My hat's off to today's constructor, Jonathan Baude.  A fine debut!

Reading today's "Constructor Notes" was a stark reminder of the hard work and dedication that these amazing people engage in to provide us with a little entertainment.
To think about the effort to get a puzzle published here, only to almost make it....if you only make a few adjustments.  And to then figure out that those small modifications make you almost start the whole thing over again!
What dedication!

[And to think that some commenters complain about "lazy constructors!!!  It makes me so mad!]

Thanks again, Jonathan Baude!  May your next acceptance come soon and joyfully!
It's Tuesday. This x-word is too cute by half. It's not wordplay. It's wearisome.

I am confused. Why does a capitAl city have a capitOl building? What is the deal with the divergent spelling? My only guess is that it alludes to the Capitoline Hill, in Rome. So Latin to English.

On a semi-related but seasonal note, "From Atlantic to Pacific, oh the traffic is terrific." Hey now, there's another one of those contronyms we learned about yesterday. Terrificus (more Latin) originally meant "terrifying" but the word has come to mean really good. So how was that traffic really, Mr Crosby?

Fun Tuesday puzzle; TOPEKA jumped right off the page for me.

So now I've solved a math problem in Spanish. What a HOOT. Nicely Toughened Up Tuesday with an interesting theme.
Congrats on publication, Jonathan.

There was a lot to chew on in this one - never heard of Froffles, but it wasn't hard to guess it indicated frozen waffles, and an excellent bit of trivia that Gmail and Islam have the same approximate number of participants.

Congratulations on a smashing success after two decades (!) of trying.  Most impressive.

An enjoyable Tuesday puzzle, made even more so by the fact that I got to solve it while sitting with my cup of coffee at hand and cats surrounding me in the morning!  Snow day here in my part of Ohio!  Congratulations on your debut, Jonathan.  You are a testament to the power of perseverance.  Here's to your next puzzle.

I lost a lot of time due to misreading "Communication syst. in which the letter Z is drawn with one's index finger" as "Communication syst. in which the letter Z is drawn ON one's index finger." Imagine my difficulty in coming up with such a language. Zen Buddhism? Zoological Universal Language? Or this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7wRHBLwpASw

Here's a nit:

[1970s sitcom title character who "can turn the world on with her smile"] : MARY

The sitcom was The Mary Tyler Moore Show, or simply, as seen on the opening credits, Mary Tyler Moore.  Eponymous to the lead actress.

The character was Mary Richards.  Ms. Moore wasn't playing herself.

There was no title character in that show.  Only a title actress who played a character with the same first name.

But that name in the title refers to the actress, not the character.

I know, close enough for crosswords.

I know, "Did it keep you from coming up with the answer?  Clues are hints, you know."

But still...why did it have to be wrong?  (No misdirection was intended, I assume.)
A splendid Tuesday puzzle.  Just the right amount of crunch.  Thanks Jonathan Baude!
Nice puzzle, but seriously, the circled squares are irrelevant.

I'm surprised nobody was triggered by 54A. 

Know what would be fun? The person who thinks that passing a cognitive function test makes him a genius has described 54A as unintelligent. He thinks being to identify an elephant from a drawing is evidence of a superior intellect. 

I would love to see a live, televised face-off where this "very stable genius" and 54A both take a legit IQ test*, graded immediately after, and the results shared for all the world to see. 

It would be hilarious. 

* Yes, I know "legit IQ test" is probably a sort of oxymoron. It would still be fun.
Fabulous debut! Hope we see you again soon, Jonathan Baude. This was crunchy and lots of fun. üòä

My usual late puzzle find. A Tuesday from July 5, 2011 by.. Andrea Carla Michaels and Johanna Fenimore. Four 15 letter grid-spanning theme entries: "Warning about a chubby guy in some skimpy swimwear?" FULLSPEEDOAHEAD "No-good, awful frozen waffle?" DIRTYROTTENEGGO "Icy winter greeting?" SNOWBALLINHELLO "Result of cleaning up some building toys?" NOLEGOTOSTANDON Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/5/2011&g=26&d=A ...

Wonderful debut, Jonathan -- I, for one, am most grateful for your tenacity and hope we'll see a lot more from you!

I had to laugh at LAV. Like many, I initially inserted "loo," but soon saw that wasn't going to work. Back several years ago when I was in junior high (now middle school) here in Portland, Maine our jr highs were grades 7 - 9 due to overcrowding at our high schools. My school's restroom passes had LAV engraved on them and, as such, we soon learned that's where you asked to go when natured called. For the first week of school as 7th graders, however, most of us kept wondering why kids kept asking to go to what we misheard as "the lab." It's the only school I ever attended where LAV was used so perhaps a more purist English teacher started that tradition (that I've always recalled with fondness!)

I do LAV finding a clean LOO when I have the runs, er, am running about. It puts me a HEAD of the game.
Ok, TAKE POT SHOTS AT me.

Low (BAUDE?) humor aside, good puzzle. Thanks, Jonathan.

PeMOVIES meant nothing to me. It had to be wrong, but what else? The Column told me, but what was GMAIL? I "Googled" it and it must be a word I've seen over and over again for years now, yet so unfamiliar to me this morning!
Thank heavens for state capitals with short names! It would have been a lot harder to find a common phrase containing EESSAHALLAT.

One more late puzzle find. A Tuesday from July 7, 2012 by Peter A. Collins. Hard to describe this one but I'll try. Fourth row from the top, with highlighted letters circled: PO(THE)AD_SM(OLD)ER Sixth row: OSO_RO(MAN)IA_ASP And below the middle - Row 10: NEW_BL(AND)LY_REP Row 12: ZI(THE)RS_IN(SEA)MS And the 15 letter answers across the very middle: ERNESTHEMINGWAY Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/17/2012&g=37&d=A ....
still working on the puzzle but just popping in to say-- can we PLEASE retire ACAI? she's had her time. she's tired. let her rest.
Fun puzzle. Bottoms up, vodka anyone?

Ok - the strangest puzzle I've EVER encountered. A Sunday from February 21, 2010 by Eric Berlin with the title: "Words from the White House." Theme clues and answers: "Anatomical pouch / Run on TV / Consume / Feel sick / Oral history" SACAIREATAILLORE "Christmas season / Greet a villain / Speak aloud / Query / Monthly payment" YULEHISSSAYASKRENT Least smart / Kitchen worker / Towel word / ___ Fein : DUMBESTCHEFHERSSINN "Trash / Victories / "Get it?" / Do some math / Runs smoothly" JUNKWINSSEEADDHUMS "Most shaggy / Hotel offering / Actress Goldie" HAIRIESTROOMHAWN And the 'reveal.' What you'll get if you read aloud 23-, 44-, 67-, 86- or 113-Across : UNITEDSTATESPRESIDENT Don't think I would have had a chance at that one. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/21/2010&g=23&d=A ....
Great debut!  Fun, thank you! :)
Does anyone know how to access the monthly bonus puzzle through the app? I can‚Äôt find it!
Congratulations on your debut, Mr. Baude!

This was SLOPPY even for a Tuesday with way to many 

CBSTV? ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs catch Colbert on CBS TV!‚Äù -Said no one EVER.

NW and W were brutal for me.  

Also, unrelated, but I got a new tattoo of Nico Nolte on my neck last night brahs.
British ‚Äúfacilities‚Äù is always LOO‚Ä¶‚Ä¶except today.  üò´

I'll re-post this one tomorrow. For no discernible reason, a 21 letter answer dawned on me (of course I had to count it out in my head): AMANAPLANACANALPANAMA And... that was an answer in one puzzle. A Sunday from January 12, 2014 by Andrew Chaikin with the title: It's only "A" game Some other answers: CATCHASCATCHCAN CASABLANCA FALALALALA STARWARS MAGNACARTA BALACLAVAS RASTAMAN ALANALDA BLACKANDTAN BAFTAWARDS And there were several others. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/12/2014&g=63&d=A ...

That was a fun, zippy puzzle! No snags that weren't easily figured out. I guess some days are better than others for all of us.  Thanks, Jonathan, for a smooth Tuesday solve, and congratulations on having your puzzle in the NYT!

I liked this theme!

CBSTV and LAV tripped me up, otherwise not too tricky and fun to solve :)
One chap's loo is another's chap's lav. Great first foray into the crossworld, Jonathan! Look forward to more. Ad astra....
Congrats to Mr. Baude! It‚Äôs nice to hear about perseverance!
Cool theme, but tbh this had several prompts I really did not enjoy and was probably my most disliked puzzle in five years
@Eli Edwards " To loo, or not to Loo,........that is the question!

@Terry

That was some type of first trickery right there.  But that‚Äôs what makes it the NYT puzzle and not the USAToday puzzle!!

@Robin

Look up "Pre-dreadnought battleship" in Wikipedia.

@Andrzej

üòÄ

It seems like I've asked this before, but maybe I haven't or maybe I've forgotten the answer...

you and a lot of other people talk about trivia.  I guess I don't really know what trivia is.  

It seems to me that I could make a case that it's all trivia.  

It also seems to me I could make a case that none of it is trivia.

But I can't make a case for saying some of it is trivia, and some of it isn't.

I'm not trying to be a Richard here...I honestly don't understand.

@Francis

Everybody has their own trivia. To me, all factual knowledge that changes nothing in my life is trivia. My national heroes are your trivia, and vice versa. Some categories to me are trivia by definition, like brands and product names. This puzzle had it all, including my most dreaded crossword entry of all, the trivial abbreviation.

@Francis

It is the only definition that makes any sort of sense. Consider what an average Pole, American and Nepali know. They are bound to be three very different sets of facts and names. Either everything is trivia or nothing is. The latter makes no sense - surely no one believes all knowledge of all facts matters equally for all people. Thus the opposite must be true ü§∑üèΩ

@Andrzej

This whole concept of "trivia" is much eelier than I thought it would be.

@Andrzej

And yet, and yet...

So you frequently accuse a puzzle of being trivia heavy, when you also freely admit that virtually everything anyone knows could both be trivia and non-trivia.

How does that help us evaluate the Coefficient of Trivia for a puzzel?

@SBK

Excellent question!  

I can't think of a single thing.  

Which is in fact why the evaluation of trivia percent is completely mystifying to me.

Which is fine with me.  A completely mystifying comment in a forum is far preferable to a completely mystifying reality in the outside world.

@SBK

Let me use a misquote (for fear of prudi5h censor5hip)

Frankly, my dear [hypothetical constructor], I don't give an emus feather.

Obviously the objectively perfect puzzle does not exist. Striving to create one is pointless. Somebody will always dislike a grid, and for reasons so personal they can't be argued with - vide me and (mostly American) trivia, or RJ Smith and rebuses. Trying to satisfy everybody will always fail because it's simply impossible.

The only thing constructors may do - and IMO, should do - is to not cross proper names, and especially not stack or bunch up crossing proper names.

If you want to construct a better definition of trivia than my own, prove to me convincingly that the name of a random sport team, their mascot, coach, stadium, MVP is of any practical importance of value to me (being able to solve puzzles is not a good enough argument, because that works for any proper name, and surely you can't expect all people to know all proper names that have ever existed).

@Andrzej

"...prove to me convincingly..."

Challenge not accepted.  I'm pretty sure I know my limitations.

But @SBK...you have the floor.

@Francis

I‚Äôll jump in. Andrzej, the problem with your definition is that trivia would be different things to different people. To Sherlock Holmes, as I‚Äôve pointed out before, it was ‚Äútrivia‚Äù that the sun doesn‚Äôt revolve around the earth because it didn‚Äôt affect his life; while for most of us it‚Äôs common knowledge. If I watch football every week the name of a quarterback or a foul rule would not be trivia but a Shakespeare character would be. So as a constructor, I am always thinking, is this information that would be accessible to a majority of the solvers? And if not can I make sure the crossings are, or at least fair enough? (I wouldn‚Äôt cross two sports terms if I could avoid but maybe I‚Äôd cross a sports term with a Shakespeare term). Also, the best ‚Äútrivia‚Äù is something the solver has heard of but perhaps not in the same context, or with some additional information that the solver could learn from. Finally, I‚Äôd try to limit the total number of entries that would be considered ‚Äútrivia‚Äù by more people, although as I‚Äôve said for a very tight theme I make more allowances for this. 
By that criteria, I really don‚Äôt think this was a particularly trivia heavy grid for most US solvers. 
My 2 cents.

@SP

*This* grid wasn't too trivia heavy, for me, since I was able to deal with it. There was more trivia than I would have liked, though.

I think what I like least about your concept of trivia is that it expects all of us to know similar things, and remember them to a similar extent. As a contratian who never follows the crowd, I find that so much against my character I will never be able to accept it. Generalizing about what the "majority of the solvers" are expected to know is worthIe55 because no two people are the same.

Also, my biggest objection is related to stacking and bunching trivia, rather than simply crossing it (which I also dislike but to a lesser degree).

Anyway, we will never agree on all the details of this ü§∑üèΩ

@Andrzej

And one more aspect of this. As a constructor I also like to think of the grid as an extension of my personality. Of course I will try to include things that I enjoy or admire (within the limits of the editors changing things). In this puzzle, MARY could have been clued a thousand different ways but (if Jonathon wrote the clue) it could be a reflection of a show he really liked and would like people to remember. Recently in a puzzle that got rejected (for other reasons) I was thrilled to clue WADDED as part of my favorite George Eliot quote, BOATS from the end of The Great Gatsby, ELEMENTS as the Tom Lehrer song since he just passed away, and DON as the main character from Singin‚Äô in the Rain, all some of my favorite things. Who knows how many of those the editors would have kept if it had been accepted, but it‚Äôs a way for me to put my character in the puzzle and maybe influence someone out there to learn about those things and enjoy them. So it‚Äôs a two way street.

@Andrzej, et al.

I find this whole discussion trivial, and I'm sorry that I wasted a perfectly good 5 minutes perusing it.

@Francis
I was spending my time in the LAMER discussion, so I didn't realize it was my turn here.

I'm in the 'no such thing as trivia' camp. I want to know about everything all the time everywhere. I want to know what the servants in Augustus Caesar's kitchen ate for lunch.  I want to know what the difference is between a skin and a hide. I want to know the name that Chinese astronomers gave the constellations and, indeed, if they even perceived the same configurations as the West does. I want to know why some metals rust, some metals tarnish, and some remain unchanged. I want to know who first thought out how to move huge objects on rollers.
Will any of that make any difference to how I live or what becomes of me? No. But I am still fascinated by it all and hope to remain so, so long as I breathe. I hope that my last words are a question.

@Kate Tani
Count me on the other side of this issue. A person whose ability to walk is limited is correctly described as LAME, just as a person whose sight is severely limited is blind. The human instinct to group, compare, and adapt means that these physical limitations will be borrowed to make non-physical limitations more concrete by implicitly comparing them to these physical conditions.
To adopt a less sensitive example, must we abandon expressions such as 'bald-faced liar' out of sympathy and support for the hairless among us? LAME is a perfectly respectable word with a clear physical meaning and a clear metaphorical meaning.
Please note that I am /not/ saying that we should not treat anyone with these challenges in any way that denigrates them or limits their lives in any avoidable way. But these words have meanings that are important and express ideas that we should be able to use.

@Nora 
People are upset by the use of ‚Äúlame‚Äù to mean ‚Äúuncool,‚Äù and my stance is: why should we upset people just to insist on our right to say something? Especially when ISLAS crossing LASER would have been fine.

When I was a kid, ‚Äúgay‚Äù was used like this. I heard ‚Äúthat‚Äôs gay‚Äù used as an analog for ‚Äúthat‚Äôs bad‚Äù or ‚Äúthat‚Äôs weak‚Äù. You don‚Äôt hear that anymore and people would be rightfully incensed to see a clue like that. People are arguing that people who are ‚Äúlame‚Äù in the original sense should receive the same consideration.

I actually think that the original sense of ‚Äúlame‚Äù has faded so much that one day the association will be gone. But since people are still upset by it, that day is not here.

@Kate Tani

I‚Äôm with SBK on this one. Yeah if I were constructing this I would probably have changed if it were convenient to do so; but not necessarily. The problem is where do you draw the line? Shall I not say someone was ‚Äúblind to her charms‚Äù or ‚Äúdeaf to his pleas‚Äù for fear of triggering someone? How about not using the R word in the context of ‚Äúto slow‚Äù (many might say no)? How about leaving out clues about drug use in case someone had a child who died of an overdose or guns for someone affected by gun violence? There is a line for words that have crossed into the realm of having almost no inoffensive context; but I don‚Äôt think LAME crosses it, and I would err on the side of being more liberal than conservative on this just on principle.

@Bill in Yokohama
I would have thought that this expression, which I read as clearly negative, would be fine as used here. We all agree that yanking a dog's chain is terrible conduct. The idiom follows that idea.

@Kate Tani
Again, thanks to all for this genuine discussion.

You raise a real issue. We send the written word blithely out into the world, not knowing who will read it or how. But how much responsibility do we bear for that which we can't control?
Let's say you send a chatty little note to your aunt and, as is your habit, you make a small joke about your uncle's limp/ stutter/ (insert other disability here). Everyone including him acknowledges and even jokes about it.
Now you hear your uncle's health has deteriorated. Do you need to apologize to your aunt about the note? Should you call her and tell her not to read it? Going forward, should you stop joking or do the jokes become a harking back to lighter times? Wait for her to make a joke? Discuss.
And that's the /easy/ example because you know the people and can tailor your response.
Another point: I am given to understand that, just as gay people have reclaimed "queer" from being used insultingly into a defiant claim for acknowledgment, so also people with physical disability have reclaimed "gimp". (I'm unsure of the status of "lame"; in my opinion, it is not inherently insulting.) Queer now seems to be an ordinary term without the built-in insult of its original meaning (although surely it could still be used that way intentionally.) But we can't read/hear tone of voice in written words.
In the end I am always for plain speaking.

@Jane Wheelaghan
I can‚Äôt imagine the version you saw: probably as appetizing as the shelf-stable cr√®me horns or Peeps in plastic at the grocery store. In the ‚Äúreal‚Äù version, the just-toasted smoky marshmallow is scraped off the roasting fork to join a Graham crackers-and -chocolate sandwich. The time between ‚Äúyou‚Äôll burn your mouth‚Äù and ‚Äúthat‚Äôs so good‚Äù is brief indeed. Has anyone ever set a partially-eaten S‚ÄôMORE down?

@Andrzej

"Decadent" has its roots in a notion of moral decay, and it reminds me of the 19th century painting by Thomas Couture, "Romans of the Decadence".  As a term relating to ethics and character, it is a derogatory criticism.  We once were noble, but wealth and laziness have led us down the path of decadence.

From there is is perhaps a short walk to "extravagance" and lavish self-indulgence.  But it's interesting how that can be seen as something desirable...so long as one does not make a habit of it!
So, a decadent dessert is lovely, but should not be an everyday occurrence.

So, back to the original question:  Can something be both decadent and unsophisticated (like an eclair)?
And now I'm back to my original answer:  "Why not?"

@Francis "However, when talking about "decadent" we're talking about price, it seems to me.  And s'mores fit a family budget far better than eclairs"

OK--so most people will buy a ready-made √©clair, but make a s'more at home, in the backyard. But, should you want to make either at home--well, the s'more requires you purchase graham crackers, marshmallows, and chocolate; the √©clair has more ingredients--flour, butter, sugar, milk (and chocolate), and a few others--each of which, however, is less expensive, pound for pound, than grahams or marshmallows.

So the (home) economics become those of time, and skill, not of cost.

(/As mentioned, there are packaged "s'mores," but they're not really worth eating.)

@Lewis

It's actually "a√ßa√≠," which says it all.

@Steve L @Lewis "It's actually "a√ßa√≠," which says it all"

When they encountered New World languages, the Spanish and Portuguese colonizers did the best they could representing the pronunciation in their own spelling systems, and many of those spellings have been preserved in English. Actually they did a pretty good job respecting pronunciation than they did of respecting the human rights of the native speakers.

Thus the pack animal is a "llama," which is pronounced "zhama" (at least in Ecuador), and the Inca emperor is "Huayna Capac"--if his emire had been conquered by the English instead, he would have been named "Wineugh Kapack."

So, "a√ßa√≠": if it was spelled with an "s" (between the two "a"s), the Portuguese pronunciation would be with a z-sound; if with a plain "c" (before a back vowel), with a k-sound. Hence the cedille, or rather, cedilha.

(Boy, my US-INTL keyboard layout is getting a workout this morning!)

ARBYS is a fast food roast beef restaurant here and the jingle should be pretty well known. LIPSYNC is a pretty common term here for pretending to sing with the music in the background. It didn‚Äôt strike me as a very trivia heavy grid when I solved it but I can see where these would be less accessible to non-Americans.

I'm sure the theme helped many people.  It's one way to unstick yourself when you get stuck.  But there are usually, on Tuesdays, people who do the whole puzzle without getting stuck even once.

If you don't get stuck, you don't even bother to see what AKEPOT and MELAS mean.  It takes longer than just continuing.  (Like if you make a typo in Spelling Bee, you just hit Enter once to guess wrong, instead of backspacing numerous times.)

@Francis (and Steve) sigh. Guys, it‚Äôs ok to admit an answer was clumsy (or, yes!, objectionable). That does not amount to conceding that the overall puzzle was bad. Heck, it does not even amount to an endorsement of the complainer‚Äôs negativity! 

Yes, I also don‚Äôt like it when people post complaints that are not counterbalanced by a compliment (or even so much as an acknowledgment of the constructor‚Äôs effort) when the crossword was good. And I like that the community will jump to keep the complainer honest. But that does not mean that *no complaint is ever valid*. 

Darren happens to be right. It doesn‚Äôt matter that such a thing as ‚ÄúCBS Radio‚Äù existed or that not every crossword answer can be neatly put in sentence form. The indisputable fact is that, at no point during Colbert‚Äôs employment at CBS has the channel employed the label ‚ÄúCBS TV‚Äù at all. And these are companies that actually do spend millions coming up with names and trademarking them.  Does it mean the term (made up as it is) is flat-out unacceptable? No, but it‚Äôs *certainly* quite open to dispute. 

If CBSTV is unobjectionable, then it‚Äôs unreasonable to complain if the answer to ‚Äúpeddler of Word‚Äù is MICROSOFTAPPS, or if ‚ÄúJapanese multimedia giant‚Äù clues SONYCOMPANY. Microsoft peddles apps, Sony is a company, and CBS is a TV station, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs unobjectionable for constructors to freely make up terms without letting us know *in the clue* that they‚Äôre asking for more than the known name.
